Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from numerous fragments with added plaster) with handle root of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; traces of added red lines on rim and a group of four on the wall; top of lip glazed; exterior: lip and handle zone reserved, black band between; upper wall glazed, reserved towards foot; glazed black on top of handle root; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1886, 0401.735. Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, it finds parallels with his Type 10.1.Ag South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 10 cups were mass produced and include numerous variants. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type V (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B1 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Numerous Type 10 South Ionian cups have been found at Naukratis, as well as in the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra and at Megara Hyblaea on Sicily, and at Berezan on the Black Sea (Posamentir 2006, 165). The place of production of Type 10 South Ionian cups is determined as probably Miletus based on the results of NAA analysis carried out by Hans Mommsen, Bon,n on another sherd (British Museum 1886,0401.1025) from Naukratis and of same shape, decoration, and fabric. The number in Petrie 1886,192, is written in ink on the exterior surface of the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXII, no. 192)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 658, no. 153)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.163) (Phase 3)
